ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course is SOOOOO interesting. You learn a lot of insights on how humans think, why they think the way they do, and the right and wrong ways of thinking. 10/10 recommend anyone to take it (you only have two chances to get into this class as a Yale undergrad). Don't get deterred by the end-of-class quizzes-- TOTALLY MANAGEABLE AND EASY if you pay attention to class.
how we think and why we think the way we think and whether it's rational / irrational.
I learned about psychological studies examining how we make everyday decisions and why we sometimes make irrational judgements.
I have a greater understanding of human processes for Thinking and gained skills that are not only applicable in my conversations with people but also in the way that I approach problems.
Psychology but in a fun way!
I learned how to summarize thoughts in the most simple ways; I learned how to avoid circular reasoning.
Some basic knowledge about behavioral psych
It was a really great insight as to how we think vs how we should think
Ways human overconfidence manifests in, biases and default (sometimes ineffective) patterns of thinking and how to work with them to have a happier and more mindful life.
I learned a lot of psychology concepts and techniques that could actually help me in real life.
A greater understanding of logical fallacies and thinking errors that we make in our daily lives (and how to stop them)!
Basic introduction to a variety of psychological concepts.
I learned how people are supposed to think and behave compared to how they actually think and behave.
Learned about biases in the way we think. Topics included decision making, judgments, rationality, confirmation bias, morality, fake news, language and thought, and creativity.
Learned so much about how to understand others/my actions through psychology, and how to redirect some of my irrational actions.

How people make decisions and form judgments; how language, creativity, and self-perception affect our view of the world; how psychological studies are conducted; how to effectively engage with and synthesize lecture material.
Psychology behind how people think in certain situations, when making decisions, evaluating probabilities, and so on. Learned how to see things psychologically.

I learned much about the ways that the human mind tends to take shortcuts when doing basically any mental process and how that can lead to biases and illogical/irrational conclusions. I liked that the course felt like an AP Psychology class as while I do not plan to major in psychology, it gave me the most practical set of knowledge on the subject that I could ask for.
I learned so much about how the mind works and how we make logic and reasoning fallacies.
insight into how we think and why we make certain decisions

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Would be better if we could see the quizzes would be available for us to see to study for the exams.

The lectures were engaging and informative with interesting studies that helped ground the abstract concepts taught in class. A weakness of this course is the structure of the exams. Some of the questions felt like we were trying to find a specific answer that the professor wants without her providing the sufficient background during lecture to make it reasonable. Also the regrading procedure for the exams felt overly harsh and punished the students for even attempting to get their exam regraded by deducting more points than the question was originally worth.
strengths - slides and recorded lectures very helpful for review and following along, lectures engaging

Strengths: interesting and engaging content. Weakness: lectures are fast paced with sometimes over 100 slides which makes it difficult to remember every single detail for the quiz at the end of each lecture.
Professor Ahn is great and funny and the engaging lectures are really well taught.

Strengths: No surprises on the exams; extremely organized.
Weaknesses: The exams are heavily weighted; I did subpar on one exam and was unable to receive an A on the course just because of that one test; there are daily quizzes which can be good/bad depending the student; the course is very much a memorization course (if you can memorize every detail of every study then you will do well; if not, it will be hard to receive a good grade)

Strengths - quizzes every lecture and no day to day homework was an engaging way to retain information and stay focused.
Weaknesses - Professor Ahn is not a supportive professor.
Strengths: Engaging lectures. Weaknesses: NONE

Strengths: low workload, very well-designed and intentional assignments (no homework, short quizzes after lectures to incentivize you to actively listen, review and discussion questions and sessions as the only prep you need for the exams), non-judgmental and supportive Professor and TAs. Weaknesses: none come to mind. There weren't a lot of office hours available, but you could always schedule a meeting with Professor Ahn.

The course is very interesting and teaches you a lot about psychology related to how people think. The only downside is that there are daily quizzes after each lecture, though they ensure that you pay attention during the lecture.

Professor Ahn is a gem!!! So funny, engaging, organized, and clear. Her lecture slides contained such a great mix of psychological phenomena and studies, relatable examples, and fun thought experiments/games to really make concepts stick in our minds. I always looked forward to coming to class because of her incredible teaching ability. I also thought the daily quiz format worked well for the class, and I appreciated having 3 exams rather than a midterm and a final. However, sometimes I wish Professor Ahn cut off students that continued to interrupt her/argue with her during class - people often seemed really combative (?) and it sometimes disrupted the flow of class, which made me sad!

It is a good basic introduction to the contents of the syllabus. But it's very basic, so if you don't think you would like the content or if you think you're already familiar with much of it, you don't need to take it.
Strength was that the lectures were almost always engaging. Weakness was that our grades were mostly comprised of quizzes and tests, so there wasn't really a way to measure effort.
The classes were fun and engaging. The exams however were graded too harshly.
no homework, but there are quizzes every class and mandatory attendance.

Strengths: the set up of this course is my favorite of the classes I have taken at Yale so far. It is organized so that you learn the material extremely well IN lecture, not through homework. I left every lecture feeling like I had learned so much. Its perhaps the only class where I feel this way after every single class. I truly think more yale classes should be organized this way (quiz at the end of the class, a discussion session every three classes, and an exam every 5-6 classes).

Strengths: organized and engaging lectures; clear expectations of students; well-explained and understandable material. Weaknesses: in some cases, certain exam questions and answers were not completely explained.

Strengths: very well organized, resourcefulness, the professor Ahn and the way she teaches her lectures. All the lectures were very interesting, not only she explained the concepts clearly, she often provided engaging real-life applications of them. I couldn't think of any weakness of this course.

Strengths: the lectures
Weaknesses: none
Everything was a strength. Everything.

strengths - interesting content, classes are recorded, TA's are nice, weakness- can be difficult to stay engaged / know how to properly take notes or study - there are quizzes at the end of every lecture and that can be intimidating at times, exams can be tricky, excelling in the class means rewatching lecture

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. Take it whenever you can.
yes, it's a fun class and the content is highly engaging. relatively low workload and stress, but be sure to pay attention during lecture - you cannot doze off

I would recommend it to someone else because the content was very interesting and enjoyable to learn. However, I would warn the student that although there is a lower workload compared to many other classes, there is a quiz at the end of every lecture. Additionally, the strict grading of free responses on exams in addition to tricky multiple-choice questions make this class not an "easy A" despite the relatively low workload. Despite the difficult grading, it was still an interesting and worthwhile course that I enjoyed.
Absolutely. Take this if you have any kind of interest in psychology, it is not overwhelmingly difficult and the content is really interesting.
YESS!! If you're at all interested in psychology or just curious, this is the class you should take! I changed my major to psych after taking this class.
Yes, as long as the student understands that the course is mainly based on recalling study details.

No - the content was simplified significantly and felt like a freshman high school course. Feedback from the professor was lackluster and often discouraging students to ask for help, for instance saying students' tests grades could be further penalized for asking about grading.
Yes, even as someone who doesn't plan to major in psychology it was really great

Yes, I would absolutely recommend it. It's not a necessarily easy to get an A in this course, but the workload is low, the material is extremely interesting and practical, and the community is very engaged and supportive. I don't regret taking the course at all.
Yes, it is a very interesting course that is fun and useful.

Yes! Low workload but high returns. I literally think about so many of the concepts and fallacies discussed in class whenever I'm making decisions in my day to day life now, and the ideas we discussed in lecture were really interesting to bring up in conversation during the semester (whether I was bringing up a fun fact or counseling my roommate through a breakup). 100% recommend!

Things to know:
1. It's a basic introduction to behavioral psychology. Ahn knows the content well.
2. There is a (pretty easy) quiz at the end of each class, so attendance is mandatory. 
3. Grading can be a little frustrating. They'll sometimes release exam grades that aren't complete and are much lower than what you'll actually end up getting. And the re-grading policy is strangely harsh for a class with short-answer questions (if they still think your answer is wrong, they may give you negative points for that question). 
4. Workload is very low.
I would recommend it because it is a fun and interesting class, however the exams were graded too harsh and you might not end up with the best grade.

I HIGHLY DO NOT RECOMMEND, solely because of Professor Ahn. She is extremely strict, and has many poor policies (you should read the course policies before taking the course!). Honestly, you might be better off just reading "thinking, fast and slow" as it basically covers the key concepts of the class.
This course is quite interesting, has practically no work, AND is super easy.  I absolutely recommend this course for a social science gut.
YES! This will be my most recommended class. You learn so much in such a well-organized manner.

Yesthe lectures are fascinating, useful, and applicable even for a non-psychology major, and involve real-world applications and exciting in-class demonstrations. I will warn that the lack of reading does not mean a lack of homework; the nightly assignments are essentially the review and discussion questions. In order to do well on the exams, you must become very familiar with the material.
Yes. If you have never taken psychology course before, this course does an excellent job in introducing one to the field of psychology.
Yes, it was a very fun course that taught useful topics in a way that means that if you pay attention you can do well.
I would absolutely recommend this course to other students. Its a low course load but so informative and helpful to apply to everyday life regardless of major.

Yes but only if you are going to credit d fail it or if you are ready to devote lots of time to it, its not really a gut. You will also be randomly called on on review and discussion days so be prepared for that.
